title: 103_s1132
content: The curr_chunk is a section header titled "SHORT TITLE; DEFINITIONS." The Act is titled the "Fair Trade in Motor Vehicle Parts Act of 1993" and defines "motor vehicle" and "motor vehicle parts" as specified in the Harmonized Tariff Schedule of the United States. The Fair Trade in Motor Vehicle Parts Act of 1993 specifies subheadings and headings related to motor vehicle parts, including compression-ignition engines, transmission shafts, chassis with engines, motor vehicle bodies, and bumpers. The Fair Trade in Motor Vehicle Parts Act of 1993 covers various motor vehicle parts such as axles, road wheels, suspension shock absorbers, radiators, mufflers, clutches, steering wheels, steering columns, and steering boxes. The Act also allows the Secretary to include other articles under the Harmonized Tariff Schedule that are deemed necessary. The term "United States motor vehicle parts manufacturer" refers to a manufacturer with facilities in the US. The Fair Trade in Motor Vehicle Parts Act of 1993 defines "United States motor vehicle parts" as parts produced in US manufacturing facilities not owned or controlled by individuals or entities from deficit foreign countries. The Fair Trade in Motor Vehicle Parts Act of 1993 defines "United States motor vehicle parts" as parts produced by US manufacturers in the country. It also defines a "deficit foreign country" as a nation with which the US has a trade imbalance of $5,000,000,000 or more in motor vehicle parts for three consecutive years. The terms "Secretary" and "Trade Representative" refer to the Secretary of Commerce and the US Trade Representative, respectively. SEC. 101. ``301'' ACTION WITH RESPECT TO BARRIERS TO MARKET ACCESS OF UNITED STATES-MADE MOTOR VEHICLE PARTS. On the 45th day after the enactment of this Act, any act, policy, or practice of a deficit foreign country that hinders access to its market for motor vehicle parts made by US manufacturers will be considered unjustifiable and harmful to US commerce. The Trade Representative will determine the necessary action under section 301(a) of the Trade Act of 1974 to address this issue. The Trade Representative will take action under section 301(c)(1)(C) of the Trade Act of 1974 regarding unfair acts, policies, or practices that hinder access to the foreign market for US motor vehicle parts. Negotiations will focus on guarantees for sales of US motor vehicle parts in the foreign market and the removal of barriers in the foreign country's motor vehicle distribution system. The Trade Representative will establish procedures for exchanging information with deficit foreign countries to assess bilateral trade in motor vehicle parts, especially regarding purchases of US-made parts. If action is taken under section 301(c)(1)(C) of the Trade Act of 1974, estimates will be promptly made based on the best available information. The Trade Representative will exchange information with deficit foreign countries to assess trade in motor vehicle parts. This includes determining the percentage share of the market for US-made parts and the potential impact of certain acts, policies, or practices. If negotiations fail, subsequent action may be taken. If negotiations fail, any action taken under the Trade Act of 1974 in response to the deficit foreign country's acts shall be equivalent to the estimated dollar value. SEC. 102 of the Act initiates an investigation into motor vehicle parts from deficit foreign countries for potential antidumping duties. SEC. 201 extends and modifies the Fair Trade in Auto Parts Act. The Fair Trade in Auto Parts Act of 1988 is amended to extend the deadline to December 31, 1998. The Secretary of Commerce's functions are expanded to include coordinating US policy on auto parts and sharing market information among relevant government departments. The Fair Trade in Auto Parts Act of 1988 is amended to include definitions for "auto parts and accessories" and "United States auto parts manufacturer". The Secretary of Commerce's role is expanded to coordinate US policy on auto parts. The Fair Trade in Auto Parts Act of 1988 is amended to include definitions for "auto parts and accessories" and "United States auto parts manufacturer". The act specifies that United States-made auto parts and accessories must not be owned or controlled by individuals or entities from Japan. The Fair Trade in Auto Parts Act of 1988 is amended to include definitions for "auto parts and accessories" and "United States auto parts manufacturer". Section 1(b)(3) of the Act is modified by changing the heading from "definition" to "definitions".
